{{knowledge objective

|Title=Knowing the definition of diagnostic errancy and diagnostic impasse
|Description=To understand the concept of diagnostic wandering, to know how to reduce it, to distinguish it from the concept of diagnostic impasse (in accordance with the instructions of the PNMR3).
|Topic=Positive diagnosis
|Contributors=Sylvie Odent
|Order=5}}
Diagnostic wandering: diagnostic wandering is the period between the appearance of the first symptoms and the date on which a precise diagnosis is made ('''[[Rational request/prescription and choice of a diagnostic examination SD-178|rational request/prescription and choice of a diagnostic examination]]''').

Diagnostic impasse: diagnostic impasse results from the failure to define the precise cause of the disease after having implemented all the investigations available in the state of the art. It concerns patients with an atypical form of a known disease, or a disease whose genetic or other cause has not yet been recognised.

question.title: What is the key difference between diagnostic wandering and diagnostic impasse?

option_a.title: Diagnostic wandering occurs when a patient's symptoms improve after a diagnosis is made
option_a.description: This option is plausible and could be a common misconception

option_b.title: Diagnostic impasse occurs when a patient's symptoms do not improve after a diagnosis is made
option_b.description: This option is plausible and could be a common misconception

option_c.title: Diagnostic wandering refers to the failure to define the precise cause of a disease after implementing all available investigations
option_c.description: This option accurately reflects the definition of diagnostic wandering

option_d.title: Diagnostic impasse occurs when a patient's symptoms improve after a diagnostic examination is completed
option_d.description: This option is a common misconception and does not accurately reflect the definition of diagnostic impasse
